Unfortunately the butterfly effect is pseudoscience. In fact when we think about it this is obviously the case. The flapping of a butterfly wing in Brazil has never caused a tornado in Texas or anywhere else.

It is used to explain contradictions in logic of scale allowing insignificant factors to be attributed major effects. This would be magical thinking and is used to overcome basic contradictions in logic when false dialogues are being introduced.

In particular use has been to support climate change narrative where trace element gasses are given fantastical properties in order to further an agenda (Agenda21) along with dubious terms such as tipping points.

For example:
Carbon dioxide at 0.04% is a 2,500th part of the atmosphere. that means to warm the climate by just 1"c carbon dioxide molecules must capture 2,500"c of heat energy. That is impossible. It also breaks the fundamental laws of thermodynamics. 

Methane at 0.00017% is a 600,000th of the atmosphere so it's even more impossible. To cause 1°c of heating methane would have to capture 600,000°c of heat energy. Problematic as this is over a hundred times hotter than the surface of the sun. (Methane rapidly breaks down in sunlight).

The CO2 hoax has been supported by geoengineering programmes and is clearly observable in the sky on a daily basis.

In short the butterfly effect is pseudoscientific nonsense and essentially a belief system equivalent to 'I don't know how but it must be so!'

Please think about the profound nonsense being passed off as true for extremely nefarious reasons.

Fun fact: even when studying ordinary differential equations (ode) you find somewhat similar conclusions.
A Cauchy's problem is a differential equation (in this case an ode) with one "initial" point (aka the solution passes through this point).

There is this math theorem that says that the local solution of the problem always exists and is unique, under some hypothesis of regularity for the differential equation (lipschitz's hypothesis).
This means that if two differents solution for the same Cauchy's problem had a point in common (=have the same value at a certain time) they are the same solution (locally). In this sense two solutions for two differents Cauchy's problem never "touch" no matter how close they are at certain point in time.

Of course this does not give you any information about the two solutions after infinite time (it is a local property) and most important: things always get weird when you go into infinites.

In the case of the pendulum there are so many variables that are so rarely accounted for: weight of the pendulum components, air density and accompanying friction, rotation of the Earth, movement in the solar system/galaxy/universe, interaction with the myriad particles that invade our space all the time, etc., etc, etc. In short Chaos theory is dependent on so many variables that are, in many cases, uncontrollable simply because they are so random. And the more random something is, the more chaotic it will seem to be. One precious video led me to understand that the next time you get the infamous "Blue Screen of Death" on your computer, it may have occurred because of a cosmic ray on its journey to some other location, a journey that happened to pass through your computer's processor at just that moment and flicked an electron in the opposite direction, thus tripping the computer's "we have a problem, Houston" subroutine. Simply no way to predict that, even as much as we rely on our computers to "always" be 100% accurate.

Typically, the problem of predicting the future is worse than presented.  In the case where one has differential equations that describe the solution space and where one tries to model (generate) solutions numerically then many of the floating-point calculations involved in the model introduce more imprecision at many/most stages in the calculations.  When I was in grad school we did not know about chaos BUT one kept doubling floating point precision to see if the model was stable.  At each step of the model calculations previous results are used effectively as inputs to the next iteration.  Essentially chaos is introduced at many floating-point calculations as the model is run.

In case you're interested:
* If you picture the Lorenz attractor as the wings of a butterfly, the butterfly effect occurs where the butterfly's butt would be: between the two wings and at the bottom of the picture. Mathematically speaking, there is one path that keeps getting closer and closer to a fixed point forever, but it's like balancing a knife on its point: even an infinitessimal deviation (e.g. from the beating of a real butterfly's wings) will push the state of the Lorenz system into one of the wings of the attractor.
* The butterfly state in the double pendulum is a periodic orbit where the lower pendulum is pointing almost directly at the upper bearing, so the oscillation of the upper pendulum provides just enough force on the lower one to keep it balanced. Just like the fixed point in the Lorenz attractor, it exists mathematically but never lasts a significant amount of time in the real world.

Ok, so chaos theory is fascinating, and this video does a great job of explaining it.

If you want to go one better though, and simulate how quantum randomness can affect macroscopic effects over time, read on!

Back when I was a CS undergrad, some students in the CIT department suggested I talk to one of their professors about simulation, because I had a habit of writing particle simulations for fun. After around two years of this, I finally did it. At the time, I was planning to write a swam simulation in Haskell. He gave me some interesting advice. He suggested I not worry about state. Normally, in simulations like this, one would use a buffering technique, so that the state currently being generated is based purely on the previous state. If you don't do this, early changes can affect later changes, blurring state between frames. I took this advice to mean that I shouldn't concern myself with this, so I wrote a simulation that advances each particle based on wherever the others happen to be _at this moment_, instead of buffering state. The result was that behavior of the simulation was far more organic, lacking artificial looking patterns that tended to show up in the state buffered simulations I had previously written.

This isn't the really interesting part though. Another thing I did to achieve this indeterminate state was to based advancement on time passed, rather than progressing a set amount per "frame". Frames really only made sense when trying to preserve state integrity, and since I wasn't doing that, I fell back to an older method I used to use when writing video games.

So, here is how the simulation worked: I started with a list of particles. During each loop, I would advance the first particle in the list, based on the amount of time passed since I had last advanced that particle (and based on the positions of the other particles in the list). Then I would move that particle to the end of the list. (Using functional programming techniques in Haskell make this extremely easy.) This completely abandoned state integrity, which did manage to achieve very interesting results.

The most interesting result, however, was what happened with, on a whim, I ran two identical instances of the simulation side-by-side. Starting them at exactly the same time randomly placed the particles in the same places. To be clear, this is the only place in the simulation where randomness was used, and because the RNG was seeded based on system time, starting them simultaneously seeded them identically. So, they started with particles in exactly the same positions, and the particles then started moving in exactly the same patterns. Except, imagine my surprise when I noticed the simulations begin to deviate. They started in identical states. There was no additional randomness going into the simulations. So they should have matched perfectly.

That final assessment, however, was actually wrong. There was still some tiny amount of randomness going in. This randomness was processor scheduling. The difference between the two simulations was the time passing between iterations. Desktop operating systems assign processor cycles to programs using some algorithm. How cycles are assigned depends on a lot of factors, including how many processes are waiting for CPU time, the priority level of those processors, how much input and output is being generated, and so on. This means that even running the same program twice, at the same time, won't give them identical schedules. Anyhow, in the context of the simulation, this means that while each particle started in exactly the same state as its parallel in the other instance, it didn't always take exactly the same amount of time between iterations, and this allowed tiny differences due to floating point error to work their way in. But, modern processors are extremely fast, so the actual differences in time were infinitesimal, barely big enough to make any difference in the floating point time values being generated, and further, the floating point error created by these slight difference were also infinitesimal. So how, after only a few seconds, could deviation be seen?

The answer is chaos theory. One might be tempted to suggest that the tiny differences would add up to big ones, but the truth is, the tiny difference should be expected to just average out. If we are basing progression on time, the differences do average out. The cumulative time that has been applied to any particle will always be within a few milliseconds of the total time passed since starting the program. And floating point error doesn't tend more toward one direction than another, so over many iterations that will also average out.

So what was actually happening was that tiny differences (perhaps on a scale closer to quantum than macroscopic) produced from effectively random influences were having the impact of chaos. Maybe an easier way to think of this is considering each iteration as a "starting condition" for all future iterations. So, the first iteration has some infinitesimal difference between the two simulations. That difference, while initially imperceptible, results in growing deviation between the simulations. And this happens _on every iteration_.

Now, this might seem like some merely interesting theoretical stuff, but it's far more than that. What degree of impact does quantum randomness have on the macroscopic world? It's easy to write it off as having literally no impact, except when we are deliberately measuring quantum effects and acting based on them. Chaos theory suggests otherwise though, and my simulation demonstrates exactly how even infinitesimal differences being added into the system on a constant basis can have a significant impact in even a fairly short period of time.

So the truth is, not only would the future be unpredictable even if it was 100% deterministic, due to chaos, our universe isn't 100% deterministic, because the various sources of quantum randomness are constantly injecting random new information into the universe, and this means that even if we could know the initial conditions with infinite accuracy and precision, we still couldn't predict the future, because tiny state changes are constantly filtering in, and those are injecting new tiny differences that chaos will eventually amplify into enormous differences.

Awesome video. I keep going back to our ability to process information. In a simple environment, say a pool ball striking another pool ball, we have the ability to isolate many points of information in that "relatively small" experiment. We can essentially tell the direct future for a few seconds. We don't really call this chaos. But when we work with a larger set of data and more points of information, we suddenly label it as chaos as we are unable to predict the outcome accurately. It's not that we are unable to predict, it's that we don't have the tools/understanding to quickly identify, map out, and "do the math". The math now resides within magnitudes of complexity. If given enough time and a massive amount of data points, (plus some wicked processing) we should be able to predict the outcome just the same. It just requires more on our part. More than we currently have.

The actual name of his publication was "Deterministic Nonperiodic Flow". The other title mentioned here was just for this meeting. Lorenz hadn't submitted a title for his speech so someone who probably didn't quite understood Lorenz came up with this one.

And there is two things wrong with concluding what we call butterflyeffect from Lorenzs work.
a) Lorenz only considered 3 variables in his model and the system was highly sensitive to changes of the initial state. In nature there are a lot more variables you might consider but a system will be robust to changes in a lot of them. So concluding that a butterfly swing could lead to a tornado is like concluding cartoon animals might actually exist because you have seen other unlikely animals in the zoo.
b) It's still an attractor pulling trajectories and one with high selfsimilarity. Actually it's almost 2-dimensional. So while it's true that the longtime behaviour isn't practically predictable in an exact manner there are of course limits on it.

I think what really catches in the idea of the butterflyeffect is that it implicates that each one of us could potentially have a huge impact on the world and the society with our tiny actions. But if there is anything to conclude from Lorenzs work to humanity it's this:
You can make a difference but it's most likely the effect of it will continously vanish over time and you are irrelevant.

Laplace was wrong :
1. As the observer, you are provoking changes in the particles around you. So to observe all the universe perfectly, you would have to be outside of it.
2. Conscience is a great particles modifier : for an obscure reason, people move in another direction that is not absolutely dependent from external causes. So you would have to observe minds too.
3. We don't know if minds are stick to determinism. But we know for sure that when someone want to prove that he can act randomly in order to escape from determinism, he can do anything and observing his mind would not help. He would just take anything around him and interact hazardously with it. Or you would have to be so fast that everything would be in slow-mo and nearly "fixed" in order to see apparition of thoughts and will in minds¹.

PS : I didn't talk about the fact that to observe the universe and calculate every positions and movements so QUICKLY that the PRESENT is not escaping from your observatory capability (in short : your calculation performs faster than all particles movements in the universe), that would necessitate to be bigger than the universe itself². And the reason why I didn't talk about it is we don't know if something exist outside of our universe and CAN or CANNOT have this capability. I prefered to focus on logical impossibilities in my three arguments above.

(¹) (²) : so, if god or any being exists and can manipulate time by dilating or contracting it because he is in a different space density... ╘[◉﹃◉]╕

Great explanation, very clear. A couple of thoughts:
1) If the solar system is only predictable to ~ 10 million years, with some planets posisbly being flung out, does that mean the solar system was totally different let's say 100 million years ago? I always assumed it has been more or less the same for billions of years, at least the orbit of the Earth must have be very close to the same during all that time.
2) For me, the image of the butterfly effect has always been somewhat misleading. Sure, in theory a butterfly could totally change the outcome somewhere far away. But in reality, there are billions of butterflys flapping their wings, and billions more of other creatures and objects causing disturbances of all kinds. With all that background "noise", it is hard to image that any of those major events could be traced back to any given butterfly, unless very close by in space and time. And even if one could prove that a butterfly caused an avalanche to go off 10000 miles away, had that one particular butterfly sat still, another one would have caused the avalanche a microsecond later. In other words, don't blame the butterfly for catastrophes, the problem is with the condition that made the situation so instable in the first place.

Planets colliding or leaving the solar system won't happen in a few million years. There is a realistic chance that Mars and Venus will collide within 5 billion years (Laskar and Gastineau, Nature, 2009), but that's on much longer time scales. On a time scale of millions of years it's only really the smaller asteroids and such that are chaotic. We can calculate the orbits of the planets in the solar system quite accurately for the past ~50 million years and the large planets (who's orbits are more stable) even further back. That's also backed up by geological data; you can find the expression of orbital cycles in the sedimentary record. Once you've identified these cycles, you can use radiometric dating to reconstruct the orbital configuration. We can actually use the geological record to identify the chaotic changes in the resonances of fundamental frequencies of the planets throughout earth's history.

Really good explanation of the concept and I'm glad you used both meteorology and astrophysics as examples. People often ask "Why can we predict where a planet will be millions of years down the line but not the weather in a week?" They're both chaotic but depend on the temporal scale much differently among other factors. A week is a long time for the weather, but for space it's nothing.

And along with that, weather models are never "correct". Their predictions may match what ends up occurring in some areas, but they can never be perfect. Even though meteorologists have moved away from doing hardcore math to make predictions because computers have allowed for more predictions to be made much more quickly, they still need humans to interpret them and to determine whether or not the outcome is realistic. This is why weather apps on your phone (The Weather Channel, etc.) are often wrong, because they're pretty much purely model output with no human interpretation. Also, ensemble runs (multiple runs often at a lower resolution to save time computing) are very useful with portraying uncertainty in a forecast and deterministic runs (single runs at a higher resolution) will likely be more accurate than any single run in the ensemble members. Both have their uses, along with taking the average of ensembles (including when your ensemble members are multiple different models rather than the same model being run multiple times).

My story of the real butterfly effect:
When I was at University I made the choice: "..not to become a scientist, but a teacher instead.." Just because of the lesson I picked up, named "Chaos" (was optional).
I had to create a computer model, for a 3 variable (+ the time) system (a simplyfied model of the Gold flow) and my teacher wanted me to find the saddle set of it. Find what makes it work? Find the particle that never leaves the system!
Of course now I know I had really no chance to find it. It cost me money and lot's of work. My teacher told me that he won't give me any grade and later I had to beg for a 1 (=fail), so I didn't have to pay even more money.
At last I lost enthusiasm and that was the point I didn't want to be scientist anymore.
Don't worry here comes the good part! But I became a teacher, still loving physics, teaching it like it's magic! Children loves it! I would never meet my wife, not even watching this video, that is posted 1 day difference of my birthday. I am thinking of now, was it a coincidence or .... ?

Randomness separate from chaotic results. An event or observed state with absolutely no reason for being. Even on a quantum level, the universe is cause and effect. It is more likely we have gaps in our knowledge and understanding of quantum mechanics than there is a chance of true randomness.

She went into surgery to get the cyst removed, and under anaesthesia, her heart kept shutting off. She was in a coma for days, and because her heart just kept failing, she was dying, and they thought she couldn't make this. This also caused inefficient blood flow to her limbs, especially her leg, which ended up dying from the lack of supplies oxygen. They had to amputate it. She's alive and healthy now, but if she literally hadn't popped that zit, she'd still have her leg.

Isn't it more logical to consider the physical phenomenon of chaotic systems to be a result of stochastic behavior than to try and generalize something that is physical into a theoretical deterministic model that we know is only an approximation. The presence of initial condition dependence is only an indication of positive divergence (in this system) being true for all real numbers. That's just mathematical continuity, it doesn't matter if its on macro or micro scale, math is math. But to act like a deterministic system model like the Lorenz system is a true physical phenomenon is not right.
It's not a coincidence that the field of science that Lorenz dedicated his life to doesn't use deterministic models. That said leaving it purely theoretical and not acting like this system has incredible profound life altering implications (which it truly does not), the Lorenz system and other nonlinear systems in which Hopf bifucation shows up are EXTREMELY interesting to work with. They are the gifts that keeps on giving and i will never get tired of it.

2:00 - YES. Exactly. If you study some physics, it's natural to come away with a determinist attitude. And I think that's a very bad thing. We teach high school physics as though it's fully correct. Students get show these equations, and they're taught that's THE WAY IT IS. That's just not the truth - we're doing them a disservice. I don't advocate actually trying to TEACH them quantum theory in high school, but I do think we should make students aware that it exists and aware that the equations learned in that early program are APPROXIMATIONS. Very, very good ones - they can learn that for all day-to-day work they're fine - but they should be told that fundamentally reality is non-deterministic.

What I loved about Lorenz was that his initial computer simulations were an early effort to prove long range weather forecasting was possible. What he got instead was the opposite. He said that if you were to place weather sensors in a grid around the earth every cubic mile in the sky, the space in between would still not be accurately measured and therefore, impossible to map long term. If you were to put sensors every 1/2 mile, the space between would be a mystery and so forth down and down the scale. That proved that no matter how much you tried to "map" a chaotic system, the space in between the measurements will throw you off over time. Therefore, a small change: like the slight turbulence of butterfly's wing could, over time, effect the system in an unpredictable way if it's "in between the sensors" and not measured initially.

① Throughout most of its history Earth had no polar ice caps and the average global temperature was between 8°C and 15°C warmer than present time.

② We are in the middle of a 2.58-million-year-old glaciation – the Quaternary Glaciation.

③ The current global warming started about 12,000 years ago. That's how the last ice age ended and the current interglacial period, the Holocene, began. This warm and cozy climate won't last forever – interglacial periods last between 20,000 and 60,000 years.

④ Between 12,000 and 7,000 years ago the sea level rose by 197 ft (60 m). Look up the Early Holocene Sea Level Rise!

⑤ The climate is always changing. There is no such thing as a stable climate. If you want to learn more about the stability of the climate, you might want to look up: The 8.2 Kiloyear Event; The Little Ice Age; The Year Without a Summer (1816).

⑥ Compared to solar activity, the Milankovitch Cycles or volcanic activity, human activity has an insignificant effect in the long term evolution of the climate. We cannot start, end, or prevent ice ages or global warmings. We're not that significant.

⑦ Chaos Theory explains how the behavior of some systems is unpredictable (chaotic). Even simple systems can exhibit chaotic behavior, like the double pendulum (look it up!). No one can predict the climate, because the climate is a stupidly complex chaotic system.

⑧ During the Hirnantian glaciation there was 10 times more atmospheric CO₂.

⑨ 95% of all greenhouse gases on earth is water vapor.

⑩ CO₂ does not fit in any way shape or form the definition of a pollutant. Almost all the oxygen in the atmosphere is a byproduct of photosynthesis – a process by which plants use light energy to produce glucose from CO₂ and water. CO₂ is used in the food industry, for example, in the production of carbonated beverages like: beer, soda, sparkling water etc. CO₂ is also used in hospitals, for example, in laparoscopic surgery.


There are many scientists who disagree with various aspects of the man-made climate change hypothesis. One of them is Ivar Giaever, Nobel laureate in physics, who said that "Global Warming is pseudoscience". Freeman Dyson said that "Climate Change predictions are absurd". Keep in mind that science doesn't work by consensus. Science isn't a democracy. As Carl Sagan put it:

Science is more than a body of knowledge. It is a way of thinking; a way of skeptically interrogating the universe with a fine understanding of human fallibility. If we are not able to ask skeptical questions, to interrogate those who tell us that something is true, to be skeptical of those in authority, then, we are up for grabs for the next charlatan (political or religious) who comes rambling along.

In general, when you're convinced of your truth, make an effort to get out of the echo chamber and listen to the opposite point of view. You might learn something.

H. Uncertainty is literally the basis of this whole video. Yes you can't predict the solar system over millions of years because we can't and don't know the exact position of planets, zooming in that far would cause us to not know how fast that planet is traveling or vice versa. To ignore that plain and simple fact pretty much ignores where the chaos comes from. Sure we can predict orbital decays through gravity waves and other effects and get a decent picture in the short term, but even then our physical constants have uncertainty in them as well. So acting surprised that using that constant over a long timespan causes chaos is pretty ignorant. No matter how much we advance our technology our computers will always have a limit in the precision they compute and our constants will always have uncertainty in them, there will always be chaos in our predictions even if you want to pretend quantum effects don't matter on the scale of the solar system.

I currently don't know if the universe is deterministic. On a large scale, it is, cause everything is predicted by classical mechanics. On a small scale, things might not be so simple, and based on probability. But that wouldn't matter cause it's small scale right? Then I thought well what if two scientists made a bet on the result of a quantum phenomenon that, to the best of our knowledge, is based on probability rather than being deterministic? Assuming this phenomenon has two possible results, there are now two possible futures. One where scientist A wins and one where scientist B wins. These two would be drastically different due to the butterfly effect, and if we had Laplace's demon, we could predict the future of both but we wouldn't know which one is going to happen. So I came to the conclusion that the universe is only deterministic if intelligent life does not observe quantum phenomena. Then I thought, is quantum phenomena really probability based, or is it actually determined by set formulae and we just don't understand it yet? If it really is a case of the quantum realm being based on probability, then would the act of time travel itself change the future? Assuming you travel back in time and do nothing, interact with no one and nothing physical at all, would you still inevitably change the future because you are 're-rolling the dice' on all the quantum phenomena that occurred in the future? I think it is interesting and that if we could time travel then we could determine whether or not it is deterministic or chance-based, but unfortunately we can't go back in time so we might not ever know unless our understanding develops to the point where we understand everything in the universe.

Chaos theory is sometimes pointed out as a contradiction to Laplace's demon: it describes how a deterministic system can nonetheless exhibit behavior that is impossible to predict: as in the butterfly effect, minor variations between the starting conditions of two systems can result in major differences. While this explains unpredictability in practical cases, applying it to Laplace's case is questionable: under the strict demon hypothesis all details are known—to infinite precision—and therefore variations in starting conditions are non-existent. Put another way: Chaos theory is applicable when knowledge of the system is imperfect whereas Laplace's demon assumes perfect knowledge of the system, therefore chaos theory and Laplace's demon are actually compatible with each other.

I’m double majoring in physics and chemistry and minoring in pure math , I developed a hypothesis that free will does exist, but limited due to the wave function.

Let’s use chemistry as an example. We can think of the chemical equations as a template of a predetermined sets of chemical solutions. You can add or subtract chemicals from the equation to arrive at the mixture you want to achieve. Basically, you can think of the expressions on the left side of the chemical equation as the present and the right as the future. If I ask you to find the present, based on the future, it is easily done in chemistry. Let say I give you Sodium chloride as the outcome. There can be multiple combinations of chemical to achieve this outcome and the most obvious one would be 2Na+Cl2. Using the other combination of chemicals instead of 2Na+Cl2 is what I meant by limited free will.

The outcome of the future is already predetermined and you are given a set or domain of choices which you have free will to choose from. It’s like finding the domain or sets of all numbers for x at which a power series converges. It is free will in a limited sense because no one is preventing you choosing choice B from A except both choices B and A must be inside the sets of choices that meets the conditions of the outcome.

This is unrelated to quantum anything, it is about feedback. A ‘rounding error’ here is essentially a loss of information about the state of the system and thus our ability to predict its future.

Take for example one of those rotating cages full of balls used for picking bingo/lotto numbers. Now every ball can be described by a set of conditions; location, velocity, mass etc. Knowing these conditions perfectly allows us to perfectly predict how each ball will behave in the future (well, that and a star sized super computer).

However, if we were to round those conditions even a little, we would no longer know exactly where the balls are, how fast they are moving etc, at the very beginning of our calculations. As a result we will soon predict that some balls will collide (or not) when in reality they do not.

These errors compound (feedback) making our prediction less and less accurate. Thus, this unpredictability is not a property of the system, but a limitation of our ability to predict its behavior based on limited information.

Stable versus unstable equilibrium:  Ball bearing rolling to the BOTTOM or a bowl versus one rolling downward from the TOP CENTER of that same bowl inverted (no matter how close to the center you try to put it).  The first will repeat pretty well with only a small variation from test to test, but the other is completely chaotic.

Not discussed here is how chaos theory can explain how to insert a tiny periodic force into a chaotic system and nudge the entire system (whether compound pendula or dripping water) toward smooth or periodic motion. This has enormous practical benefits, yet is not generally known.

There is a software technique called Pearson's Hashing that uses chaos to map a string of characters into a pseudo-random number. If you change any of the characters by just one bit, no matter how many characters are in the string, you get a dramatically different hash number. (Although the original paper limited the hash number to the range 0-255, this limit has since been eliminated.)

Chaotic systems follow deterministic rules and there behaviour is a result of a chain of causal events from a set of initial conditions.

If a butterfly flaps its wings a chain of events occurs that causes a hurricane elsewhere in the world.

My problem is that this analogous picture of chaos leads you to believe that the butterfly has a choice to flap its wings.

This choice is then a perturbation in the initial conditions of the system and thus the outcome of the system is drastically altered to that if the butterfly did not make that choice to flap its wings.

My point is that if chaotic systems follow deterministic cause and effect then the butterfly would always take the choice to flap its wings and the hurricane was always destined to happen.

How then can you say small pertubations in initial conditions cause significant outcomes in chaotic systems when it could be that the entire chain of events is simply an inevitable unchangeable consequence of deterministic cause and effect from the initial conditions shortly after the Big Bang.

It seems that only in a closed, predictable, linear and periodic system would the butterfly effect be easily confirmed. A small cause would travel a linear and predetermined path towards its result in a larger end. However, in our chaotic universe, the answer itself is chaotic. Sometimes yes; sometimes no - without any predictability. The flap of a butterfly's wings creates swirling and chaotic air currents that follow no predetermined pattern, and as their energy dissipates, eventually find balance at zero. Could these air currents then combine with some other chaotic system and then eventually lead to a larger outcome? Of course. Can this be plotted or predicted? Of course not. Chaos is the cause, the system, and the answer.

Hey Derek, here’s one for you to take on:

I have a Mathematician friend who dismisses man-made Climate Change thus (super-short summary):
1. Take the famous NOAA ~135-year annual global-average temperature data,
2. Difference it year-on-year and take the standard deviation,
3. For illustration create 20 (say) random walks with that standard deviation, and
4. Show us mathematically why an overall 1ish-degree temperature increase beats the Null Hypothesis that it’s all just a chaotic/random system.

My responses, which didn’t impress him or the others monitoring the conversation, were:
1. Why are you just looking at these 130-some-odd data points, and ignoring the other 99% of the relevant data?
2. Climate is unequivocally a very-complex system, and (potentially at least) chaotic, but that doesn’t necessarily mean that a random walk is a plausible model.
3. What do you propose is truly random in Climate? Quantum effects are for-sure truly random, but clearly they can’t be significant in this large a system.
4. If the goal is to prove-or-not human influence upon climate, then you have to model the system extremely accurately and rule out all other possible influences until the only remaining explanation is human-generated effects. I can’t independently vouch for whether Climate Science has done that, but I can definitely say that this random-walk analysis hasn’t!

I conceived of such an effect when I was just a kid.  I had no idea what the butterfly effect was.  It just dawned on me at a very early age: "What if I decided NOT to kill that ant, or throw that pebble into the pond?"  If the ant were left alive, it would have changed the dynamics of his colony.  Perhaps that ant happened to be the one that was going to find a major food source for the nest and leave its trail.  And the pebble scared a frog and made him go a different way and he coincidentally found a fly and ate it because he moved a different way.  Then, from these small changes, there is a cascading effect that gets bigger and bigger with time.  Eventually, one of those tiny choices would become SO amplified that the date at which life on Earth ceases to exist can be affected or humans could become extinct sooner, or later, or go from never being able to colonize another planet to BEING able.  The outcomes are endless if you go far enough into the future.  To me it seemed obvious that this was the case.  When I told my friend Harry my thoughts on it, he thought I was crazy.  He couldn't see past the initial (insignificant) action.

I think that your commentary about the Solar system stability needs more clarification. Yes, the Solar system is chaotic on the interval about 4-420 million years. But it only means that we can't predict the position of the planets on such long timescales. The orbits of the planets are much more stable (but still chaotic, though on a timescales of several billion years). So, there is pretty low chance that after several millions years the orbits of the planets will move significantly and the planets will collide, but we can't predict where exactly the planets will be on their orbits. If the orbits were unstable on a timescales of 10 million years, how could the Еarth survive so long with liquid water and complex life on it for billions of years?

Excellent video, especially 11:23. Biological systems love chaos, not for its randomness, but on the contrary for its amazing stability and resilience. E.g., the heart is a chaotic system, with a strong attractor, so it usually beats very regularly. If you push a few heart cells away from their regular state, the whole system will quickly come back to a regular beat. If the heart was a linear system, then small perturbations would add up over time, and the heart would eventually fail. Paradoxically, chaotic systems can be quite stable and resilient. Like the brain or democracy.

A Mathematician once stated the chaos of nature using the example of a pool table:
" During the familiar game of pool, if a man is to calculate the collisions between the balls, the prediction of the first collision is simple enough that any college student can do it. NO. The spinners are NOT chaotic. There are other factors in play that are UNMEASURED. Air currents, microscopic dimensional irregularities between different ones, microscopic compositional differences - the fact is, there IS a reason, for ALL of the actions. All those things accumulate and compound giving an effect that is solely the result of an incomplete measurement of the differences between the spinners.

Calling it "chaos" is as absurd as a Californian believing in their personal psychic. It's pure and utter bunk.

Weather is not chaotic. Anyone who thinks that is a fool. It's just too difficult to precisely model. Period. The permutations of trillions of molecules with trillions of compositions and trillions of directional momentum are just too much to calculate (directly, without estimating and correlating). The number of currents and subcurrents and densities in just one single system is practically infinite. Actually it's not, but it might as well be. If there are a trillion different movements of air and vapor in one specified volume, let's say one cubic acre, in one slice of time, say, a millisecond, then if there are 3 possible independent actions each movement could take in the next slice of time, you've got one trillion cubed outcomes - in two milliseconds.


Even if we could calculate the virtually unfathomable count of outcomes, do we have one trillion microbe sized sensors in the first place? And this is for just one system, one cubic acre. It might cost the entire wealth of the world to precisely measure a quarter mile of movement. Not much use to tell what the system will consist of and be doing tomorrow morning, 300 miles away. Calling it "chaotic" is a cowardly way of avoiding that it is just too granular for measurement. That is, precise measurement. Sample measurement, and taking tendencies and correlations, might get it right X% of the time. But that's just because the measurement and calculations are too staggering for any human or computer. Just because you're too weak to solve a mathematical question, you don't get to call it "chaotic". It's simply not. It's just that the permutations are too voluminous.

"Chaos theory" is as bunk as Californian personal psychics. Chaos theory is a lame cop-out to the dilemma that some things - like weather - consist of so many trillions of molecules, with trillions of state changes every, oh, millisecond (I'm being nice), that just to measure any starting point is beyond human or mechanical capability. And no computer could calculate the exact permutations for even, say, one minute. The best that weather forecasting has is sample measurements and correlations, and that's right only X% of the time. All that other "stuff" that is too voluminous and costly to measure(so we don't) - gives rise to the cop out answer that "it's chaotic."

The job of an atmospheric scientist is literally to predict the future state of the extremely complex and multivariate set of dynamical systems that constitute the Earth's atmosphere. This was one of the best and most concise educational videos about chaos theory I've ever seen and should help viewers better understand the difficult challenges that forecasters in any physical domain are tasked with on a daily basis. Once again, thank you Veritasium, for another enlightening, entertaining, and educational video! :)

I read the book "Chaos" when I was in high school. That was at the behest of the only teacher we had who possessed a PhD (which happened to be in biology from the University of Michigan). He wondered if I could explain it to him.


I could not, though I do have a reason WHY not. Chaos is not a predictable, though complex science applying mathematical models to determine the future state of controlled systems - it is merely a cry for help. What is amazing to me is that anyone with a brain can try to say with a straight face that they can even IDENTIFY all the variables in a natural system; let alone quantify, rank, and CONTROL them - and it doesn't matter a damn even if you limit that to a man-made system under laboratory conditions.


The best we can do is come up with a simple set of general approximations, and then offset that with a dose of "fudge factor" until our predictive calculations somewhat mirror first-hand observation. Also, don't kid yourself that time is the only negative factor affecting even these calculations. Time, proximity, and scope/magnitude all combine to throw a monkeywrench into the applicability of system models.


Do I have any advice on handling "chaos"? Not much, other than to keep your models simple and their scope as narrow as possible - and to reboot the model as necessary in order to make predictions better fit with observable data. Beyond that ... some things are best left to God.

When I was a heat transfer/fluid mechanics engineer I had such a difficult time explaining problems to the machine designer because so many of their designs were much more deterministic. A tightened steel bolt's stress goes up nearly linearly with torque until it breaks. Trends in thermo-fluid systems are often surprising and counter-intuitive in comparison. A dropping inlet temperature of a glycol water mixture cooling a liquid-gas heat exchanger increases its ability to transfer heat then can suddenly drop the ability to transfer heat keeping everything else constant because flow goes from turbulent to laminar and you don't know when or where or what geometry until you calculate it. Gleick's book "Chaos" was one of the first books I read after college and it that confirmed my sinking suspicions about the limits of human understanding.

So, you brushed over quantum mechanics in this discussion, but it's implications on the question of predictability and determinism are much more profound, IMHO.  The unpredictable nature of a chaotic system is fundamentally a question of precision and, as you point out, it does not destroy the deterministic nature of a system.  The future of a chaotic system is absolutely determined by its present conditions and if you could, in fact, know the state of a system with absolute precision, the future state could also be known.  The implications of chaos are much more about the limit of our own knowledge as mere mortals and its implications on our ability to predict the future and understand the patterns the may evolve given those limits.  It has very practical consequences, but understanding chaos just made us better understand the implications of limited knowledge on even slightly complex system.  Quantum mechanics, on the other hand, changed our fundamental understanding of the nature of reality and sounded the true death knell of determinism.  While QM helps us understand the probability of certain futures, to put it simply, it is fundamentally non-deterministic and relies an pure probability without certainty.  To get a little philosophical, science, at it's core, emerges from our observed existence in which we find that modeling our experiences of reality allows us to build an understanding of that reality most notably marked by our ability to make and test predictions using those models.  The system of science then refines or replaces those models as dictated by our experiences and the ability of the model to accurately predict those experiences.  Yet in QM -- at our deepest understanding of our reality as derived from science -- the model itself requires true, pure unpredictably for an accurate description of the reality we experience.  So science, which relies on our ability to build and refine models graded by their power to predict our perceived reality, has led us to a model that demands pure unpredictability as a core tenet of that reality. at 6:58 in the video the three particles split into different sides of the butterfly loop.
It was a cycle before. now one of the particles has reached "Escape Velocity"
if each wing of the buttery was a funnel. (all particles with a negative X value go left. all particles with a positive x value go right) the particle that went right TWICE reached a point where it had the energy to escape the path it was originally on.

imagine a rain drop half way down a slope. it goes downhill to the left.
a second rain drop 1 inch to the right. it still falls to the left.

now go to the peak of the slope. one rain drop barely to the left will still fall left. but a rain drop one inch to the right will now fall to the right.

It is NOT chaos and unpredictability. it is the razors edge of outcome choice. like cresting a wave. in the example its a binary state.
the particle WILL either go left or right. the pattern of left or rights differ as the simulation continues. it grows EXACTLY like a triangle fractal.

something either does or does not happen. anywhere on the scale of "almost" happened does not matter if it does not reach the razor edge of outcome choice then the path does not change. the event does not happen.

Best example: Choosing to buy a candy bar. Its a binary state. either you DO or you DONT.
The X value could be -100. you walk by the candy bar without thinking of it.
The X value could be -25. you consider the candy but walk past.
The X value could be -1. you put the candy in your cart, but at checkout you decide not to buy it.
the X value could be +1. you put the candy in your cart. but at checkout you didnt want to just leave it in a random spot. so you buy it instead of putting it back.
the X value could be +100. you went to the store specifically for the candy and nothing else.

If you put the half way point between both attracters in the butterfly example at 6:58 (x=0) then any value less than X=0 WILL go left.

Chaos is actually really helpful for putting determinism in relative terms. If determinism were to be the case in the universe, it would have quite daunting implications. Morality would be irrelevant. You couldnt be held accountable for your actions. Et cetera. The philosophical implications are endless. Physicits tend feteshize determinism and the computability of the future of the universe because it gives their science a seemingly godlike power, like the Laplace-demon. Also they understand this as their task and their final goal.
But really, determinism would be a human catastophy, if it were to spread into everbodies minds and behaviour. Chaos, even though, as i understand it, is not due to normative incomputability but due to human insufficiency, it maintains the illusion of free will (of the human beeing) in the dimension of physics. And I think that to be for the better.

I find it fascinating how chaos in a bigger picture can again become something predictable...

example:
thermodynamics: chaotic movement of molecules...still we can predict the drop of temperature (increase of entropy) of a coffee in a room..

mechanical physics: spill a bucket of balls, bouncing against each other in a chaotic fasion... but on a bigger scale, they all move in the same (similar) direction...

you could bring same examples about fluid dynamics..

animals in nature: a swarm of fish... pure chaotic movements, each fish moving little differently, but at the end they end up at the same place..

and at some point those lredictabilities might become something chaotic again on a much larger scale... and on an even bigger scale its maybe even something predictable again..

Engineering is far from perfection, but the art of managing the imperfect and incomplete to still achieve a product that has a known probability of how reliable it is in some predefined usecases.


Sorry for the complicated sentence, but it is important to me that ppl understand that any product is subject to corrosion, erosion, fatigue, enthropy and other processes, which jeopardize its function ultimately. You could say that a such device would be a time machine suffering from a butterfly effect, the longer into the future the more it will fade into chaos.

Determinism on the scale above atoms is demonstrably false. The indeterminacy of quantum events does not wash away, or average out.
This can be shown easily by the following thought experiment.
A scientist is observing an event on the quantum scale that is fundamentally indeterministic. He makes a note in his note book about the outcome of the event. The universe on the macro scale is now different than how it would be had the quantum event played out differently.
Therefore, the universe is NOT deterministic on any scale, only for special initial conditions can certain deterministic events play out. In general, even the macro scale is vastly indeterministic, fundamentally.

It has seemed obvious to me for some time that the macro scale universe cannot be deterministic, why do philosophers and scientists always seen to consider the macro universe being totally deterministic to be a possibility? I have demonstrated this to be untrue. The universe is vastly richer than we can conceive.
There is a true infinitude of possible macro states the universe can occupy, and consciousness itself seems to be able to reach into the very depths of nature, and guide the macro scale universe on a quantum level.

I fundamentally disagree with the implications of this video. The intent seems to be that the world is deterministic but we just cannot predict it because we don't have enough information, but if we look to quantum mechanics it tells us that the universe, at it's core, is nondeterministic. Truly random. The Heisenberg uncertainty principle doesn't state that we can never perfectly know the position and momentum of a particle, but more fundamentally it states that the position and momentum of a particle are never perfectly defined at the same time. This may seem like semantics but it is very important. If we follow our current understanding of quantum mechanics, the universe is not fundamentally deterministic. Even if you theoretically knew literally everything about a system you could still not predict it's evolution

What interests me is at what scale do things really stop being deterministic? I have long maintained that in a given situation, at a given time, a person presented with multiple options may think they are choosing from the option, but that the choice they make is the only choice they could make.

This relies on the idea that past life experience and influences are what guide your decision making, and that if you make a choice without introducing a random selection (ie coin toss, draw from a hat etc), your choice was deterministic. As much as you would like to think you could have picked a different option - you really could not - otherwise that would have be the option you chose.

This is something that many people dislike and will reject our of hand, because it essentially removes free will, and many people find it impossible to conceive that they are not fully autonomous in their thoughts and decision making.

The original concept was about seagulls, not butterflies :-) It was first presented to the public at a conference of The New York Academy of Sciences in 1963 and published same year ("THE PREDICTABILITY OF HYDRODYNAMIC FLOW"). In the concluding paragraph, Lorenz wrote: "When the instability of a uniform flow with respect to infinitesimal perturbations was first suggested as an explanation for the presence of cyclones and anticyclones in the atmosphere, the idea was not universally accepted. One meteorologist remarked that if the theory were correct, one flap of a seagull's wings would be enough to alter the course of the weather forever. The controversy has not yet been settled, but the most recent evidence seems to favor the sea gulls." - https://nyaspubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.2164-0947.1963.tb01464.x

Fact of the matter is this is just another scientific theory, relying on pretty good ingredients, never established through experimentation.

Like a vast number of other theories in the field of modern cosmology and beyond, including these which directly oppose the butterfly effect theory.

The thing with experiment is, one of the most strict requirements for it to produce valid results is a stable, controllable environment within which the experiment is conducted. So that the conditions under which the experiment yields a particular set of results can be replicated exactly and a theory tested in practice.

Now, please beg your pardon if I tend to get all pedantic over this but...we barely only begin to understand the most basic fundamentals of the quantum realm. Like, the most basic stuff...particle, or wave, probability clouds and such...

In short we are a tiny grain away from being clueless as to what constitutes matter, energy, forces etc.

Under such circumstances how is any scientific experiment that was ever used to validate or disprove any theory in the history of theories, to be considered credible in the extraction of safe conclusions?

Why would anyone bother with any of that anyway? We've been through this before...nobody really understands quantum physics!

And most experiments use equipment that relies on classical physics, anyway so that's that.

This weird segregation, built upon mutual reliance that exists between the quantum and the classical realm, where there's different sets of rules that apply separately for each yet somehow all add up to the unified reality we all experience never fails to baffle.

It's almost as if one might suggest that the tiny grain of understanding that may be obtained at any specific point in space and time, is always sufficient for the purpose of navigating the tiny grain of this vast cosmos, that we all inhabit.

In my Calculus 2 class, we have been studying how to calculate Taylor Polynomials for a certain function, and it just occurred to me, while I was watching this video, that these are also chaotic systems. A function with infinite derivatives cannot be fully approximated using a Taylor Series. For example, the square root function has infinite derivatives, because the exponent continues to negative infinity, completely skipping over zero. Fortunately, Taylor Series are still useful for approximating complicated polynomials. Also, they can be useful to approximate infinitely differentiable functions to an extent. It would be difficult to approximate sqrt(3724) using sqrt(16), but it can be accurately approximated using sqrt(3721), which is 61. Anyway, I thought that was cool.

"Unfortunately, the corresponding series converges very slowly. That is, obtaining a value of meaningful precision requires so many terms that this solution is of little practical use. The Butterfly Effect, essentially, is the result of adding zero into the world. ...And then unbalancing the + and - equilibrium.


Zero can be just a number, which is a scalar quantity and extends into a +1 dimension. No form, no place.
Zero can be a point, an origin, which would be the zeroth dimension.
Zero can extend towards an infinite amount of dimensions, defining nothing... a point... a way... a plane... a space... et cetera.


By recognizing the existence of nothing, we can create something. Even if there was already everything in place and moving along as determined. By introducing zero into a predictable system, we can make it chaotic.

For the interested, I highly recommend the Nova episode from 1989, "The Strange New Science of Chaos" as an introduction of the subject and includes the butterfly man himself, Ed Lorenz, explaining the discovery of his eponymous attractor.

There are good reasons why humans' capacity to control the development of their societies has failed to progress. In order to control the development of a society you would have to be able to predict how the society would react to any given action you might take, and such predictions have generally proven to be highly unreliable. Human societies are complex systems-technologically advanced societies are most decidedly complex-and prediction of the behavior of complex systems presents difficulties that are not contingent on the present state of our knowledge or our level of technological development.

Unintended consequences are a well-known problem with the design and use of technology. The cause of many unintended consequences seems clear: The systems involved are complex, involving interaction among and feedback between many parts. Any changes to such a system will cascade in ways that are difficult to predict; this is especially true when human actions are involved.

Problems in economics can give us some idea of how impossibly difficult it would be to predict or control the behavior of a system as complex as that of a modern human society. It is convincingly argued that a modern economy can never be rationally planned to maximize efficiency, because the task of carrying out such planning would be too overwhelmingly complex. Calculation of a rational system of prices for the U.S. economy alone would require manipulation of a conservatively estimated 6xl013 (sixty trillion!) simultaneous equations. That takes into account only the economic factors involved in establishing prices and leaves out the innumerable psychological, sociological, political, etc., factors that continuously interact with the economy.

Even if we make the wildly improbable assumption that the behavior of our society could be predicted through the manipulation of, say, a million trillion simultaneous equations and that sufficient computing power to conduct such manipulation were available, collection of the data necessary for insertion of the appropriate numbers into the equations would be impracticable, especially since the data would have to meet impossibly high standards of precision if the predictions were expected to remain valid over any considerable interval of time. Edward Lorenz, a meteorologist, was the first to call widespread attention to the fact that even the most minute inaccuracy in the data provided can totally invalidate a prediction about the behavior of a complex system. This fact came to be called the "butterfly effect" because in 1972, at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Lorenz gave a talk that he titled "Predictability: Does the Flap of a Butterfly's Wings in Brazil Set Off a Tornado in Texas?" Lorenz's work is said to have been the inspiration for the development of what is called "chaos theory" -the butterfly effect being an example of "chaotic" behavior.

I was around 15 years old when I first read about the Butterfly Effect and how a butterfly flapping its wings somewhere can cause a hurricane on the other side of the earth...
At that time I was only just beginning to learn about Newtonian Physics and how equations could be written down describing the collision of two objects and the transfer of momentum...So the butterfly effect immediately struck me in my head that how a system full of trillions of molecules i.e. The Atmosphere behaves and a small initial push can magnify into such a noticeable result...
I didn't have internet then so I started thinking about this and then realized that given enough data and processing power we could just know the position and velocity of each particle in our atmosphere and predict our weather forever...
This thought then became prominent and then I realized that if the position and velocity of each particle is known we could not only know the upcoming weather or the future events but also figure out the past (All of it) speak of dinosaurs or Hitler or anything
But the question still remained that how would one come to know about the position and velocity of each particle in existence...
Not only storing and processing that data would be impossible but also the fact that it would make you THE GOD literally!
Knowing every event that occurs in all of History, Present and the Future.
I rushed to my 8th-grade school physics teacher and tried to get his brain wrapped around all this with the fuzzy language and nontechnical terms for everything. It took him a solid 3 days to reply but he then introduced me to Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle and that is how my journey of curiosity began in the voyage to understand the universe...
Not soon after my 10th grade, Society got the good of me and I had to give up my dreams of studying theoretical physics for the rest of my life.

Sensitive dependency on initial conditions: The exact present exactly predicts the future, but the approximate present doesn't approximately predict the future.

Accuracy of predicting future is a function of two variables, 1. Accuracy of the information on the initial conditions and 2. How far in the timeline you want to predict. But keeping accuracy of the prediction aside, I truly believe Past, Present and Future has already happened, and we the mysterious life forms are just passing through each of the frames and experiencing it with our perception of time, without any control whatsoever

This is the basis of my view of free will. Uncertainty (strengthened by Bell's Theorem) shows that there are some initial conditions, like exactly when and how strongly a neuro will fire. That do not have precise values. And there are chaogic systems (like the neural networks in our brains) that chaotically depend on those conditions. Thus, there is no present answer to what the state of our mental conditions will be in the future, beyond some near term answers and some attractors making some situations more likely than others.

So that is freedom. It isn't total freedom, but it is a system that freely evolves. The will is the decisionmaking process in your brain. As I just showed, your will is free.

I have more arguments showing that this is a kind of free will that should be accepted. I am aware of the common objections about randomness vs. freedom. But I can only put so much into a comment.

I think the 'Butterfly effect' has a flaw, or is at least misleading.
It suggests two attractors: the (flying) butterfly - which is governed by aerodynamics, and the (blowing and turbulent) typhoon - governed by thermodynamics.
Chaos theory states that each and every attractor demonstrates 'chaos' in a system; that a system (an attractor) in isolation will experience chaos - without any other external influence.
The real butterfly effect to me is more like.. 'the flapping of a butterflies wings could explain the presence, or existence, of the large (747) jet aircraft flying today - which is aerodynamics; or the heat emitted from the butterflies breath, could explain the typhoon, which is thermodynamics.
